user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetFsInfo:
```c
int32 OS_GetFsInfo(os_fsinfo_t *filesys_info)
{
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filesys_info);

    memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info));

    filesys_info->MaxFds     = OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES;
    filesys_info->MaxVolumes = OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS;

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeFds;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeVolumes;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetFsInfo:
typedef struct
{
    uint32 MaxFds;      /**< @brief Total number of file descriptors */
    uint32 FreeFds;     /**< @brief Total number that are free */
    uint32 MaxVolumes;  /**< @brief Maximum number of volumes */
    uint32 FreeVolumes; /**< @brief Total number of volumes free */
} os_fsinfo_t
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t matchfunc, void *matcharg, osal_objtype_t objtype,
                              OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    iter->match = matchfunc;
    iter->arg   = matcharg;
    iter->limit = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(objtype);
    iter->base  = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(objtype)];

    return OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, objtype, &iter->token);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    memset(token, 0, sizeof(*token));

    /*
     * Confirm that OSAL has been fully initialized before allowing any transactions
     */
    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER &&
        OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * only "exclusive" locks allowed after shutdown request (this is mode used for delete).
     * All regular ops will be blocked.
     */
    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState == OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER && lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    /*
     * Transactions cannot be started on an object type for which
     * there are no actual objects
     */
    if (OS_GetMaxForObjectType(idtype) == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }

    token->lock_mode = lock_mode;
    token->obj_type  = idtype;
    token->obj_idx   = OSAL_INDEX_C(-1);

    if (lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        OS_Lock_Global(token);
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    if (token->lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        OS_Unlock_Global(token);
        token->lock_mode = OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE;
    }
}
...
bool OS_FileSysFilterFree(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    return !OS_ObjectIdDefined(obj->active_id);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS 0x0B
...
#define OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES 50
...
#define OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS 14
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The reported fragments are those that involve loop control and state mutation relevant to assessing compliance with MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.2 (well-formed loop control). The two while loops in OS_GetFsInfo use a function call as their loop-condition; that function (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext) has persistent side effects (it increments iter->token.obj_idx and updates token state), and thus these call-sites should be investigated for whether the loop control and side-effects meet the intent of the rule. The implementation of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext is included because it performs the index increment and uses a do..while loop with side-effects and a break; its behavior determines the loop-counter semantics and whether only a single loop counter is used/modified. The transaction init snippet is included because it initializes the iterator token (obj_idx = OSAL_INDEX_C(-1)) and acquires locks, which is part of the iterator's loop-control initialization and may affect whether the loop counter is properly set and not modified elsewhere.

All other code fragments were not included because they do not affect loop control in a way relevant to Rule 14.2: simple parameter checks (OS_CHECK_POINTER), the memset of filesys_info, the assignments of MaxFds/MaxVolumes, the increments of FreeFds/FreeVolumes within the body (these are simple counters unrelated to the iterator loop counter), OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit/Destroy call wrappers themselves (aside from the iterator init/token manipulation already flagged), OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel/Unlock logic (cleanup, not loop control), and the simple predicate in OS_FileSysFilterFree (it only queries an object id) do not by themselves create the loop-control patterns that the rule addresses. These non-reported fragments therefore do not need investigation specifically for MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.2.
